item.title: [Java] Image Loader
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

This was pretty much to test my knowledge of how to use a GUI even though I haven’t learned about GUI’s in my book yet. It’s pretty much from stuff that I’ve seen. What it does is, when you run the program (with the batch file / through cmd) you supply an argument of the file path. It then resizes the window to the size of the image. [I’m having a bit of trouble with this as it’s off a bit when resizing the window, if anyone could help with that, it would be great!] It’s not very useful, but It was just practice for me.

Pictures:

Code:

Frame:

[code=java]//imports
import javax.swing.*;

//Frame class
public class Frame{

Panel panel = new Panel();

public Frame() {

    JFrame frame = new JFrame();
    frame.add(new Panel());
    frame.setTitle("Image Loader" + " (" + Panel.imgPath + ")");
    frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
    frame.setSize(panel.getImgX(), panel.getImgY());
    frame.setVisible(true);
    frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);

}

public static void main(String[] args) {

    Panel.imgPath = args[0];
    new Frame();

}

}[/code]

Panel:

[code=java]//imports
import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.;

//Panel class
public class Panel extends JPanel {

Image img;
public static String imgPath;

public Panel() {

    ImageIcon i = new ImageIcon(imgPath);
    img = i.getImage();

}

public void paint(Graphics g) {

    super.paint(g);
    Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g;

    g2d.drawImage(img, 0, 0, null);

}

public int getImgX() {

    int x = img.getWidth(this);

    return x;

}

public int getImgY() {

    int y = img.getHeight(this);

    return y;

}

}[/code]
